interestingcomments.content: My R4S has the similar problem, may not be the same as your SL, but I hope this helps you. On my R4S, when the light condition is out of its sensing range (mine is too dark, but may also apply if it is too bright), the shutter indicator will not show anything, but a downward triangle in the viewfinder will be on or blink. I heard most Leica R have this "improper lighting warning".
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: My R4S has the similar problem, may not be the same as your SL, but I hope this helps you. interestingcomments.content: On 12/12/2019 at 3:23 AM, LocalHero1953 said: ...I've experienced banding with fluorescent lights with the fp... Same here... experienced banding under fluorescent lighting when fast shutter speeds are used.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: On 12/12/2019 at 3:23 AM, LocalHero1953 said: ...I've experienced banding with fluorescent lights with the fp... Same here... experienced banding under fluorescent lighting when fast shutter speeds are used.

interestingcomments.content: Yes, I did say this - and I mean it, too 😬 Normal contrast, indoor lighting, not too bright, not too dark. I have not tried tracking. Honestly, I think my S2 is extremely precise in focussing. Not the fastest, of course. I did a shooting a couple of months back - not a single misfocus attributable to the camera.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Yes, I did say this - and I mean it, too 😬 Normal contrast, indoor lighting, not too bright, not too dark. I have not tried tracking. Honestly, I think my S2 is extremely precise in focussing. Not the fastest, of course. I did a shooting a couple of months back - not a single misfocus attributable to the camera.

interestingcomments.content: Very curious to see what you learn about metering. My brain can’t fathom why something that measures light with the sensor should know the difference between a less brightly lit scene, a reduction in light from stopping down, or a neutral density filter. All have exactly the same effect on the light intensity hitting the sensor.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Very curious to see what you learn about metering. My brain can’t fathom why something that measures light with the sensor should know the difference between a less brightly lit scene, a reduction in light from stopping down, or a neutral density filter. All have exactly the same effect on the light intensity hitting the sensor.
